description.en: Created in 1958 and modernised in 1998 under a convention between the Institut National des Sciences de l’Univers (INSU) and the University of Addis Ababa. Now operated by the Institute of Geophysics, Space Science and Astronomy (IGSSA). A 17-kilometre light train line opened on 20 September 2015. Large distubances are, since then, present on recordings

Now operated by the Institute of Geophysics, Space Science and Astronomy (IGSSA). A 17-kilometre light train line opened on 20 September 2015. Large distubances are, since then, present on recordings

instruments: DI-flux Theodolite Zeiss 010B Theodolite & Bartington mag01H
Homocentric fluxgate vector magnetometer (IPGP VM391)
Overhauser effect proton scalar magnetometer (GEOMAG SM90R)
Proton scalar magnetometer (GEOMETRICS G856)
algorithms:
Formula for computing non-reported elements:
X=H*cos(D), Y=H*sin(D), tan(I)=Z/H
D is expressed in minutes of arc.
H=SQRT(X*X+Y*Y), tan(D)=Y/X, tan(I)=Z/SQRT(X*X+Y*Y)

Formula for computing non-reported elements:
X=H*cos(D), Y=H*sin(D), tan(I)=Z/H
D is expressed in minutes of arc.
H=SQRT(X*X+Y*Y), tan(D)=Y/X, tan(I)=Z/SQRT(X*X+Y*Y)

description.en: From the 1st of January 1901, the new observatory in Val-Joyeux becomes the French National Magnetic Observatory.
description.fr:
From the 1st of January 1901, the new observatory in Val-Joyeux becomes the French National Magnetic Observatory.
In 1936, the Val-Joyeux Observatory will cease observations with the arrival of electric tramways, the development of power lines and industry in the Paris region.

organisation: Institut de Physique du Globe de Paris (France)
